image.altText: A wide shot of a US Navy ship with troops lined up in uniform along its length

items.synopsis: The US says it is sending more air defences to the Middle East and has extra forces on stand-by to "assist in the defence of Israel". Follow live.

title.children: US sending extra air defences to Middle East, as Israel strikes 'terrorist compound' under West Bank mosque

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Palestinians have again been warned by Israel's military to move south out of north Gaza ahead of an impending ground invasion. This time, however, the warning included language telling Gaza's residents they could be identified as "an accomplice in a terrorist organisation" if they chose to stay. The message was delivered via leaflets written in Arabic and marked with the IDF name and logo, as well as by audio messages sent to mobile phones across Gaza yesterday. The Reuters news agency translated the message as: "Urgent warning, to residents of Gaza. Your presence north of Wadi Gaza [a stream running through the Gaza Valley] puts your life in danger. Whoever chooses not to leave north Gaza to the south of Wadi Gaza might be identified as an accomplice in a terrorist organisation." Israel's military later attempted to clarify the message, writing on Twitter that the translation which had made its way across the internet was "imprecise", and the IDF "has no intention of considering those who have yet to evacuate as a member of a terrorist group". "The IDF states, once again, for the safety of Gazan civilians, that they should evacuate to the south of Wadi Gaza. All those who remain are endangering themselves due to the Hamas' terrorist activities within civilian areas," it wrote.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: IDF tells Gazans to move south or risk being seen as terrorist accomplices

props.alt: A brown tank and other military vehicles stand on some brown dirt.

children.content: An Israeli tank near the border with Gaza on Sunday.
(Reuters: Violeta Santos Moura)
Palestinians have again been warned by Israel's military to move south out of north Gaza ahead of an impending ground invasion.
This time, however, the warning included language telling Gaza's residents they could be identified as "an accomplice in a terrorist organisation" if they chose to stay.
The message was delivered via leaflets written in Arabic and marked with the IDF name and logo, as well as by audio messages sent to mobile phones across Gaza yesterday.
The Reuters news agency translated the message as:

"Urgent warning, to residents of Gaza. Your presence north of Wadi Gaza [a stream running through the Gaza Valley] puts your life in danger. Whoever chooses not to leave north Gaza to the south of Wadi Gaza might be identified as an accomplice in a terrorist organisation."
Israel's military later attempted to clarify the message,
writing on Twitter
that the translation which had made its way across the internet was "imprecise", and the IDF "has no intention of considering those who have yet to evacuate as a member of a terrorist group".

"The IDF states, once again, for the safety of Gazan civilians, that they should evacuate to the south of Wadi Gaza. All those who remain are endangering themselves due to the Hamas' terrorist activities within civilian areas," it wrote.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says Australian authorities are working with 77 Australian citizens, permanent residents and immediate family members who are stuck in Gaza as the conflict rages on. They are also helping 60 Australians and immediate family members in the West Bank, the minister says. "We understand this is a very distressing time and we're working on all options — including advocating with Israel and Egypt to secure safe passage out of Gaza," Senator Wong said. Earlier this week the ABC was told the government was working to help 46 Australians get out of Gaza. Australians who need assistance leaving Israel or the Palestian territories should register with DFAT's Crisis Portal or call the 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre on +61 2 6261 3305 (from overseas) or 1300 555 135 (from within Australia).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Penny Wong says 77 Australians, residents and family members are in Gaza

children.content: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says Australian authorities are working with 77 Australian citizens, permanent residents and immediate family members who are stuck in Gaza as the conflict rages on.
They are also helping 60 Australians and immediate family members in the West Bank, the minister says.
"We understand this is a very distressing time and we're working on all options — including advocating with Israel and Egypt to secure safe passage out of Gaza," Senator Wong said.
Earlier this week the ABC was told the government was working to help 46 Australians get out of Gaza.
Australians who need assistance leaving Israel or the Palestian territories should register with
DFAT's Crisis Portal
or call the 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre on +61 2 6261 3305 (from overseas) or 1300 555 135 (from within Australia).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good afternoon. I'll be running the blog from here in Brisbane until later this evening, with contributions from the international team as well as our correspondents on the ground in the Middle East. It's mid-morning in Israel right now, and Syrian state media is reporting that the country's two major airports, in Damascus and Aleppo, were struck by Israeli missile strikes earlier in the morning. A military source has told state news agency SANA that one civilian worker was killed at Damascus Airport and another was wounded. Both airports' runways were damaged, putting them out of service, and flights were rerouted to the Syrian port city of Latakia, according to Syria's transport ministry.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel takes out Syria's two main airports: reports

children.content: Good afternoon. I'll be running the blog from here in Brisbane until later this evening, with contributions from the international team as well as our correspondents on the ground in the Middle East.
It's mid-morning in Israel right now, and Syrian state media is reporting that the country's two major airports, in Damascus and Aleppo, were struck by Israeli missile strikes earlier in the morning.
A military source has told state news agency SANA that one civilian worker was killed at Damascus Airport and another was wounded.
Both airports' runways were damaged, putting them out of service, and flights were rerouted to the Syrian port city of Latakia, according to Syria's transport ministry.

image.altText: A promotional image for Super SA.

items.synopsis: For the second time in under two years, thousand of people have been caught in a cyber-attack where information tied to an SA government agency — but held by a third party — has been hacked. Here's what we know about the latest breach.

title.children: This data hack impacted thousands in SA but took months to come to light. Here's what we know

image.altText: A man with a serious expression stands in front of a cafe with red umbrellas

items.synopsis: The government says the state is not immune to global pressures on energy costs, as it announces partners for a major hydrogen project in Whyalla.

title.children: SA power prices remain key issue, as hydrogen project progresses

image.altText: A close up image of an SA Police car.

items.synopsis: Police say they have charged a 48-year-old man with murder, a day after a woman's body was found at a house fire at Aldinga Beach.

title.children: Man charged with murder following house fire south of Adelaide

image.altText: wine bottles

items.synopsis: The decision comes ahead of PM Anthony Albanese's visit to Beijing. Tariffs of up to 220 per cent were imposed in 2020.

title.children: China agrees to review tariffs on Australian wine ahead of PM's visit to Beijing

image.altText: Victoria police officers

items.synopsis: Police say it's believed four children were in a shed at Corio, in Geelong, when it caught fire. Emergency services were called just after 10:30am.

title.children: Two children die, two others injured in Geelong shed fire

image.altText: Iris Leeson sits with her baby on her lap, sitting next to husband, reading book to baby

items.synopsis: Ms Leeson said losing her mum was isolating and lonely, but now she's found a community of women who have been through significant loss and are finding ways to support one another.

title.children: Iris's mother died when she was 19. Now she's helping others experiencing grief

image.altText: A woman wearing a blue denim jacket and red glasses.

items.synopsis: Landlords across Victoria say they are selling off their investment properties, citing issues such as rising costs and changing regulations as those pushing them away from housing.

title.children: Alison says she tried to do the right thing by tenants, but being a landlord became too complicated

image.altText: a woman with dark hair smiles directly at the camera leaning her chin on her hand

items.synopsis: For more than two decades, Penny kept up a facade of being fine — but she often felt like she was "going insane".

title.children: The hidden symptoms of OCD that make some cases difficult to diagnose

image.altText: A woman with silver hair holding a baby looks out at a window. They are silhouettes.

items.synopsis: Her 15-year-old grandson is being held in the youth unit at a maximum adult prison in WA. Her concerns follow what's understood as the first young person's death in detention in WA.

title.children: 'Shock' and 'disbelief' as grandmother of teenager detained in controversial Unit 18 fears for grandson

image.altText: A marble bust of Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius

items.synopsis: Ancient philosopher Marcus Aurelius on online meetings, hot-desking and what to do if you send an email to a friend but accidentally reply-all to the whole company.

title.children: What would Marcus Aurelius make of people who have their camera off during online meetings?

image.altText: Seven children stand in a line, 4 girls are in a green school uniform while two boys and a girl wear bright clothing

items.synopsis: Th outback NSW town's population halved in five years, but things are looking up as more young families start calling the area home.

title.children: After its primary school shut, Pooncarie was almost a ghost town. Then families moved in

image.altText: Protesters hold banners at the Riverlea housing project.

items.synopsis: Protesters at a government-backed housing project in Adelaide's north are condemning the way Aboriginal ancestral remains are being treated.

title.children: Protesters condemn excavation of 'one of the largest findings' of Aboriginal ancestral remains

image.altText: A dark, moody photo of a woman wearing a green sweater laying on her back, reading a book

items.synopsis: When my 25-year marriage broke down, I did what I always do in my life, especially in times of crisis. I turned to books. Specifically, to books by women, writes Jane Gleeson-White.

title.children: After my divorce, I soaked in the words of women writers. Here's what I learned about feminism — and myself

image.altText: A group of children play on a pile of rope at Kurisa village.

items.synopsis: The global transition to electric vehicles is driving rapid expansion of Indonesia's nickel industry — but do the benefits outweigh the costs?

title.children: The booming EV market is driving up demand for critical minerals. Here's what that looks like for Indonesians

image.altText: Headshot of a young man with a moustache with a kitchen in the background

items.synopsis: Mateo Veneracion never thought he would fall victim to a sextortion scam, but he is among a growing number of young men being targeted on social media.

title.children: 'The potential to ruin my life': Mateo was targeted by sextortion scammers, and he's not alone

image.altText: A light-brown half-grown feral pig stands in mud.

items.synopsis: A conservationist says feral pig numbers have exploded after successive wet seasons in northern Victoria and western New South Wales, as a coordinator is appointed with a $13 million budget to eliminate them.

title.children: NSW to kill 87,000 feral pigs in next eight months to control 'tripled' population

image.altText: Whatsapp icon on a phone screen.

items.synopsis: The aged pensioner had an old couch she was wanting to get rid of, so she tried to sell it online. This simple decision resulted in the loss of faith in her bank — and saw more than $1,000 taken from her account.

title.children: Virginia's bank refunded her when she was scammed. Then the scammer produced a 'delivery confirmation'

image.altText: A large crowd of sad people, seen from behind two people standing

items.synopsis: Oria Rosenberger is an Israeli who wants peace and is planning to leave the country. But when her brother was sent to the frontlines, it put her in a delicate position.

title.children: Coming here is 'everyone's worst nightmare', but in Israel, it's where the biggest crowds are

image.altText: Drone footage shows flattened Gaza neighbourhood after Israel airstrikes

items.synopsis: The first 20 trucks bearing aid since Israel began a siege of Gaza pass through Egypt's border crossing, as Israel's military says it plans to step up its attacks on the area.

title.children: First aid reaches besieged Gaza, as Israel says it plans to 'deepen' attacks before ground invasion

image.altText: An illustration of an Indigenous flag at half mast on a gloomy evening

items.synopsis: Ask an Aboriginal person how they define reconciliation and the answers are not flags, morning teas and welcomes-to-country. Their answers are land rights, greater autonomy and treaties, writes Bridget Brennan.

title.children: For some, reconciliation can never be revived after the Voice loss

image.altText: A view of Victoria with felt reports from an earthquake represented by colourful squares.

items.synopsis: A magnitude-5.0 earthquake recorded near Apollo Bay just after 2am, which was felt by thousands of Victorians and even some in Tasmania, is the largest recorded in the Otway Ranges.

title.children: Warning of aftershocks after earthquake near Victoria's Great Ocean Road sets record for region

image.altText: A woman and a man sit in a car with helmets and headsets. They are smiling.

items.synopsis: Thirty-one teams from across the world will spend the next five days racing solar cars down the middle of the country. But not all of them are expected to cross the finish line.

title.children: Friendly rivalries and solar power fuels futuristic drivers racing across Australia

image.altText: A young woman and man stand either side of an older man wearing a brimmed hat, beneath a tree canopy in front of a knotted tree

items.synopsis: When Sarah and Corey Brazendale started the first ever brewery on King Island, it prompted a visit from a veteran farmer who had something on his family's property that they needed to see.

title.children: A young couple started up an island’s first ever brewery. They stumbled on a secret 140-year history

image.altText: Kids running in playground

items.synopsis: Most concussions don't happen on the sports field. Brain injury is a risk for everyone — and a single knock can have lasting consequences — but it is under recognised in the community and can be difficult to get support.

title.children: Ettie fell over playing 'monster, monster'. She's still feeling the impact of concussion 18 months later

image.altText: People enjoying the beach at Noosa on a sunny day

items.synopsis: A report into spiralling rent prices has found some Sunshine Coast residents are spending up to 60 per cent of their income on rent, with social housing groups saying some locals are being forced out.

title.children: Tenants forced to consider leaving coastal towns as rent rises hit 'severe crisis' levels

image.altText: A frowning man stand in front of a hive crawling with bees.

items.synopsis: As the industry works out what's next in learning to live with the deadly parasite, search warrants have been issued as part of the federal government's investigation into the suspected illegal importation of bees infected with the pest.

title.children: Beekeeper calls for industry exit package as search warrants issued in hunt for varroa mites' source

image.altText: Man wearing green shirt in hospital bed with needles in arms, donating stem cells.

items.synopsis: A quarter-century after he lost his daughter to a genetic disorder, Albany man Kriss Lawson's stem cells have helped save another person's life. But Australia is facing a critical shortage of donors.

title.children: Kriss donates stem cells to honour his daughter's memory — and he wants more Australians to do the same

image.altText: A map of Australia with a red circle taking up much of western and southern NSW representing a possible asteroid impact crater.

items.synopsis: Researchers say an asteroid impact crater up to 520 kilometres in diameter could lie under a the town of Deniliquin.

title.children: The largest asteroid crater ever found could be under a country town in southern NSW

image.altText: A photo of a swimmer under the water.

items.synopsis: Not satisfied with breaking the 50m backstroke record, Australian star Kaylee McKeown tops her own 100m world record in Budapest.

title.children: A day after setting a world record in the 50m backstroke, Kaylee McKeown betters her own 100m mark

image.altText: A man looks dejected after a fight.

items.synopsis: Alex Volkanovski speaks about the mental strain of downtime as his Russian opponent pays him high praise after brutal TKO.

title.children: Emotional Volkanovski reveals mental battle as Russian opponent pays high praise after brutal loss

image.altText: A diver walking along grass next to SES tent on river bank

items.synopsis: The body of a 36-year-old man who jumped into the Fitzroy River on Thursday night while allegedly trying to flee police has been found by a member of the public.

title.children: Body of man, who died allegedly trying to evade police, pulled from Fitzroy River

image.altText: Bobby Charlton

items.synopsis: Bobby Charlton, who survived the horrific Munich plane crash to become arguably England's greatest player, dies aged 86.

title.children: 'Absolutely without peer': England mourns the death of a football icon Bobby Charlton
